titlestmt.titleproper: The Kathe Sandler Collection, approximately 1973-1992, bulk 1984-1992, COL 8 (VAE0320)
titlestmt.subtitle: A Guide Her to Holdings at the Indiana University Black Film Center/Archive
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by BFC/A staff

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-07-02 04:03:18 -0400.

change.item: Finding aid updated by Ronda L. Sewald
Finding aid edited and encoded by Ronda L. Sewald

did.abstract: The Kathe Sandler Collection contains 16mm film and sound outtakes, original negatives, other film and pre-production elements, and transcripts from A Question of Color and Remembering Thelma.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open to the public. Audiovisual materials are located off site at IU's Auxiliary Library Facility and may require the creation of reference copies. If you are interested in reviewing the contents of the audio or video recordings in this collection, please contact the BFC/A staff well in advance of your visit for details.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Kathe Sandler is an award-winning independent filmmaker known for the documentaries Remembering Thelma (1982), and A Question of Color (completed 1992, distributed 1993). Remembering Thelma received the Best Biography of a Dance Artist Award from the NY Dance Film and Video Festival; A Question of Color received two Prized Pieces Awards from the National Black Programming Consortium. Her other work includes The Friends (1996), which won First Prize in the Cross Cultural Category from the Black Filmmaker's Hall of Fame, Finding a Way: New Initiatives in Justice for Children, and contributions to A Tale of Two Schools, Beah: A Black Woman Speaks, and the PBS documentary Every Mother's Son. In 1996 she was awarded a John Simon Guggenheim fellowship for film. Her forthcoming work includes a one-hour documentary When and Where We Enter: Stories of Black Feminism.

Sandler graduated from New York University and is currently pursuing a Ph.D. in Women's and Gender Studies at Rutgers University. As is also an instructor at Rutgers and president of Film Two Productions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Kathe Sandler Collection contains 16mm film and sound outtakes, original negatives, other film and pre-production elements, interviews, and transcripts from A Question of Color and Remembering Thelma.

A Question of Color was the first documentary to confront the attitudes that many African Americans have about their appearances. Sandler interviewed a number of African Americans who provided testimony of their experiences and attitudes regarding color. Through the experiences of their testimony, Sandler examined the effects of "color consciousness" upon the black community. The roots of the phenomenon are traced to the preferential treatment that mixed race children would receive during the era of slavery, the effects of which are still present today.

Remembering Thelma is a short and vigorous profile of Thelma Hill. Hill was an American silent movie comedian and dancer who appeared in scores of short films during the 1920s and 30s. Remembering Thelma contains rare footage of Hill with the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater and the New York Negro Ballet.

list.item: Series 1. A Question of Color interview transcripts
Series 2. A Question of Color film elements
Series 4. Audio recordings and viewing copies

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Collection was donated to the BFC/A by Kathe Sandler on May 25, 2010. 10 additional film reels were received on June 5, 2018.

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: All requests for copying and publishing materials must be submitted in writing to the BFC/A archivist. In cases where an author wants to quote material from the collection in a non-scholarly publication, they must obtain Kathe Sandler's permission.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [item], Kathe Sandler Collection, COL 18, Black Film Center/Archive, Indiana University, Bloomington.
